titleStmt.title: A Poem humbly addressed to Serjeant Bettesworth.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Now Dick the Second reigns like Dick the First. Dunciad.
as Brothers of a German Heir
The Title not the Riches share;
So you, poor Dick, for all your Sweat'sworth,
at Bar are titled, Serjeant Bettesworth;
While your first Brother's spreading Claw
Leaves you as little Cash as Law:
In Parliament, from side to side,
You ev'ry diff'rent Party try'd,
Who\add路m\ like a Foot-ball kick'd and spurn'd,
Each wishes to the other turn'd,
and tho' from this to that you rang'd,
You ne'er one Man's opinion chang'd;
The Words deep lab'ring from thy Breast,
as if by some foul Fiend possess'd,
Ne'er more except the vaulted Stone,
Which hoarse retorts the jarring Tone:
and thus, poor Dick, you're still the same,
a Beggar both in Purse and Fame.
But lo! Behold the Dean prepares
To send you down to distant Years,
And joins you to a fitter Brother,
Like you, as one Egg's to another;
Di\del路g路add路c\k Bettesworth, coupled to Dick Tighe,
While Verses live shall never dye:
all future Bards, who wou'd denote
A Coxcomb with a restless Throat,
No longer Stentor's Name shall use,
But with Dick Bettesworth's Name shall abuse;
Thus thou shalt be the Scourge of all,
Who like thy self shall senseless bawl;
Nor thou alone, for lo! the Dean,
Hath mixt you with a num'rous Train,
His Verse, much like his Inundation,
Joins ev'ry Dunce of ev'ry Station,
From noble Lords, to second Serjeants,
unskill'd in either Texts, or Margents;
Lo! Allen, with a swelling Maw,
Sails like a Heap of filthy Straw,
While by his side you bowl along
Dirty and black, like new-dropt Dung;
Still blacker by the Doctor's Ink,
The more you stir the more you stink;
all Grub-Street at thy Sight rejoice,
And hail thee Brother, with one Voice;
Well pleas'd in Hell, the Damn'd they grin,
When \damage\ poor Sinner \damage\ters in,
And, as like them, you feel the Rod,
You curse the Dean, and they curse God;
Scold, Vapour, Bully, chafe, and roar,
This each lash'd Dunce hath done before.
Hark, how the Dicks with equal heat,
Poor Swift! thy sudden Ruin threat!
Like Pylades and mad Orestes
United both; but then the best is,
Tho' thus they swagger, fume and rage,
They're only Bullies of the Stage.
But Bettesworth hath a Knife, beware,
He threatens Vengeance on your Ear:
Poor Swift! Alas! shou'd he but treat
Thy Ears at such a cruel Rate:
As ours, who must his Speeches hear,
Thou hadst, indeed, just Cause to fear.
And then he vows with venom'd Spight,
To answer whatsoe'er you write:
Poor Swift! what dreadful Threats are those!
Then you must hear his Verse and Prose,
But ah! Poor Dick, the Dean's Intent,
I'm told, is what you write to print:
Like a prick'd Scorpion by this Whim,
You'll sting your self instead of him.
As never Monarch yet has bow'd,
To mingle with the' ignoble Croud,
But to some petty Serjeant leaves,
The Care of prosecuting Thieves:
To me, O Swift! thou King of Wit;
This little Felon then commit,
And while thy Cares a Nation claim,
We soon will gibbet up his Name.
